content.text: Mould the piece of modelling clay into a shape that is approximately a cube. Measure the height \(h\), width \(w\) and depth \(d\) of the piece of modelling clay
Calculate the volume \(V\) of the piece of modelling clay using the equation \(V = hwd.\)
Measure the mass \(m\) of the piece of modelling clay using the balance provided
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the modelling clay using the equation \(\rho = \frac{m}{V}\)
Method 1
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 1.1. You are provided with a piece of modelling clay
Using the **smaller** piece of modelling clay, measure its mass \(m_{\mathrm{s}}\)
Pour approximately \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of water into the measuring cylinder. Record the volume of water \(V_{1}\) in the measuring cylinder
Tie the thread around the smaller piece of modelling clay and lower it into the measuring cylinder until it is completely covered with water. Record the new volume \(V_{2}\)
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{s}}\) of the modelling clay using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{s}} = V_{2} - V_{1}\)
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the modelling clay using the equation \(\rho = \frac{m_{\mathrm{s}}}{V_{\mathrm{s}}}\)
Method 2
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 1.2. You are provided with a beaker containing water at room temperature
Break the piece of modelling clay into two pieces with one piece approximately twice the size of the other piece
Assuming that the experiment has been carried out with reasonable care, suggest
reasons why the two values obtained for the density of the modelling clay may not be the same
[Total: 10]
In this experiment, you will determine the density of modelling clay by two methods
Pour \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water into the beaker labelled \(\mathbf{A}\). Measure and record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{c}}\) of this water
Pour \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker labelled \(\mathbf{B}\). Measure and record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{h}}\) of this water

As soon as you have taken the temperature, pour the \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of water from beaker \(\mathbf{A}\) into beaker \(\mathbf{B}\). Briefly stir the mixture then measure and record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}}\) of the mixture
Calculate the gain in thermal energy \(E_{\mathrm{c}}\) of the cold water using the equation
where \(k = 210 \text{J} /\text{°C}\)
Calculate the loss in thermal energy \(E_{\mathrm{h}}\) of the hot water using the equation
where \(k = 210 \text{J} /\text{°C}\)
State whether your experimental results support this suggestion and justify your statement by reference to your results
statement
justification
Suggest a practical reason in this experiment why \(E_{\mathrm{c}}\) might be different from \(E_{\mathrm{h}}\)
A student suggests that all the thermal energy lost by the hot water is gained by the cold water. \(E_{\mathrm{c}}\) and \(E_{\mathrm{h}}\) should therefore be equal
Another student was asked to suggest quantities that should be kept constant
experiment is repeated in order to check the readings. Table 2.1 shows the suggest
Place a tick \((\checkmark)\) in the second column of the table next to each correctly suggests quantity

table.html:
suggestion
avoid parallax errors when taking readings
number of stirs
room temperature
starting temperature of cold water
starting temperature of hot water
use only two or three significant figures for the final answers

In this experiment, you will investigate the energy changes that occur when hot water are mixed
You are provided with a supply of hot water and a supply of cold (room temperature) water
Switch on. Measure and record in Table 3.1 the current \(I\) in the circuit and the p.d. \(V\) across a length \(l = 0.250 \text{m}\) of the wire \(\mathbf{PQ}\) as shown in Fig. 3.1. Switch off
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of the length \(l = 0.250 \text{m}\) of wire using the equation

of the wire and its resistance \(R\). Show your working

In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of a wire
You will use the circuit shown in Fig. 3.1
Place the screen about \(1.0 \text{m}\) from the illuminated object

Place the lens between the object and the screen so that the centre of the lens is at a distance \(u = 0.200 \text{m}\) from the object. Adjust the position of the screen until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen
Measure (in metres) the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen
Record the values of \(u\) and \(v\) in Table 4.1
Repeat the steps in (i) – (iv) using values for \(u\) of \(0.250 \text{m}\), \(0.300 \text{m}\), \(0.350 \text{m}\) and \(0.400 \text{m}\)
Calculate the values of \(\frac{1}{u}\) and \(\frac{1}{v}\) and enter them in the table
Plot the graph of \(\frac{1}{\sqrt{}} /\frac{1}{\mathrm{m}}\) \((y\text{-axis})\) against \(\frac{1}{u} /\frac{1}{\mathrm{m}}\) \((x\text{-axis})\)
Use the graph to find the intercept on the \(y\)-axis
Use the graph to find the intercept on the \(x\)-axis
State and briefly explain one precaution you took in order to obtain reliable measurements
precaution
explanation

In this experiment, you will investigate the formation of images by a converging lens
